title: Trump to bring back Benghazi interrogator Trey Gowdy as outside counsel to fight off impeachment
text:
Donald Trump is bringing in a staunch Republican ally and former member of Congress to lead the fight against the impeachment inquiry into his presidency.

Trey Gowdy, the former Republican congressman from South Carolina, has agreed to act as outside counsel for Trump and lead up the impeachment fight.

He was at the White House on Tuesday to discuss the matter with the president, according to multiple reports.

Gowdy will not be joining the White House staff but work outside of the administration.

Trey Gowdy, seen here when he was a Republican congressman on Capitol Hill, will lead the impeachment fight for Donald Trump

Gowdy was at the White House Tuesday to meet with President Trump

During his time in Congress, Gowdy came to national prominence in 2014 when he chaired the House's select committee on Benghazi, a panel that examined the 2012 terrorist attack there and also helped discover the secret, private email server of then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.

Gowdy did not seek re-election in 2018, saying he wanted to return to his legal career.

There was some speculation Trump could appoint him to the federal bench but Gowdy joined the law firm Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough LLP and became a contributor to Fox News.

He has, however, been let go from his contributor gig.

A FOX News spokesperson said Gowdy has been terminated and is no longer a contributor, the network announced on Wednesday afternoon.

He also has a background as a federal prosecutor.

While in Congress, Gowdy served on the House Intelligence Committee when Representative Adam Schiff was the ranking Democrat on the panel, making Gowdy familiar with the man leading the impeachment inquiry into Trump.

His addition to the Trump team is an indication the White House has realized it needs outside fire power in its battle over impeachment.

Trump, initially, had seemed opposed to setting up the kind of war room that Bill Clinton aides established in the 1990s to fight his impeachment inquiry.

The president sees himself as his own best communicator and takes to Twitter to fight his own battles.

And the administration issued its declaration of political war against Democrats on Tuesday when White House Counsel Pat Cipollone fired off a scathing eight-page letter to Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the Democrats leading the impeachment effort, accusing them of trying to overturn the 2016 election with their probe.

'Put simply, you seek to overturn the results of the 2016 election and deprive the American people of the President they have freely chosen,' he wrote.

Cipollone also announced that neither the president nor his staff would cooperate in the impeachment inquiry.

'Your unprecedented actions have left the President with no choice,' he wrote. 'In order to fulfill his duties to the American people, the Constitution, the Executive Branch, and all future occupants of the Office of the Presidency, President Trump and his Administration cannot participate in your partisan and unconstitutional inquiry under these circumstances.'

Cipollone danced around the issue of a full House vote on an impeachment inquiry, stopping short of directly calling for one, because the GOP would likely lose in the Democratic-controlled chamber and some Republican lawmakers would be uneasy about being put in the politically tough spot of having to go on the record.

Trey Gowdy came to national prominence when he chaired the House's select committee on Benghazi, where then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton testified in 2015

White House counsel Pat Cipollone included political red meat in his scathing letter to Democrats on impeachment

Trump has attacked both Intelligence Committee Adam Schiff and Speaker Nancy Pelosi

Pelosi had a strong response of her own.

'Mr. President, you are not above the law. You will be held accountable,' she said in a statement Tuesday night in response to Cipollone's letter.

'This letter is manifestly wrong, and is simply another unlawful attempt to hide the facts of the Trump Administration's brazen efforts to pressure foreign powers to intervene in the 2020 elections,' Pelosi said.

'Despite the White House's stonewalling, we see a growing body of evidence that shows that President Trump abused his office and violated his oath to 'protect, preserve and defend the Constitution',' she continued.

'The President's actions threaten our national security, violate our Constitution and undermine the integrity of our elections. The White House letter is only the latest attempt to cover up his betrayal of our democracy, and to insist that the President is above the law,' Pelosi said.

Trump has reacted furiously to the impeachment inquiry, using obscenities and insulting nicknames for Democratic lawmakers in posts on Twitter.

On Wednesday morning, the president tweeted over 30 times in a three hour period, switching from railing about the impeachment inquiry into his presidency to justifying his decision to remove U.S. troops from Syria - a move that earned his criticism from lawmakers in both parties.

'The Do Nothing Democrats are Con Artists, only looking to hurt the Republican Party and President. Their total focus is 2020, nothing more, and nothing less. The good news is that WE WILL WIN!!!!,' he complained at one point.

Trump blocked EU Ambassador Gordon Sondland from testifying before Congress Tuesday

And he lashed out at his favorite target, Schiff, the chairman of the Intelligence Committee who is leading the impeachment probe.

'Adam Schiff is a disgrace to our Country!,' he tweeted.

Tuesday's back-and-forth between the White House and the Speaker's office offered a taste of the battle to come.

It followed Trump's decision to forbid European Union Ambassador Gordon Sondland from testifying before Congress as scheduled - the administration's opening volley in the day's battle.

Democrats, in response, issued a subpoena for Sondland to appear before them next week.

The Democrats warned Sondland if he doesn't show up, even at the request of the president, it would be seen as an obstruction of their impeachment inquiry.

‘Your failure or refusal to comply with the subpoena, including at the direction or behest of the president, the White House, or the State Department, shall constitute further evidence of obstruction of the House’s impeachment inquiry and may be used as an adverse inference against you and the president,’ the letter to him states.

Democrats called the president's blocking of Sondland from testifying Tuesday an 'obstruction' into their impeachment inquiry as the White House signaled it was ready to play hardball with their investigation.

'We consider this interference to be obstruction of the impeachment inquiry. We will be issuing a subpoena to Ambassador Sondland for both his testimony and documents,' House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff, Oversight Chairman Elijah Cummings and Foreign Affairs Chairman Eliot Engle said in a joint statement Tuesday afternoon.

Sondland was scheduled to testify Tuesday morning voluntarily - meaning no subpoena had been necessary - when his attorney announced Sondland had been directed by the State Department not to appear, an order he had to obey as a department employee.

In addition to hearing from the ambassador, Democrats planned to question him about additional texts and emails that Schiff said were in his possession and were germane to the Democrats' investigation into the president.

The president argued he'd be sending his ambassador into a 'kangaroo court' if Sondland testified.

'I would love to send Ambassador Sondland, a really good man and great American, to testify, but unfortunately he would be testifying before a totally compromised kangaroo court, where Republican’s rights have been taken away, and true facts are not allowed out for the public to see,' the president tweeted on Tuesday morning.

There have been questions about the role Sondland, whom Trump appointed as ambassador to the European Union, played in relationship between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.

Trump often acts in his own defense, making his case on Twitter and to journalists

President Trump was on a Twitter tear Wednesday morning, issuing several tweets about the impeachment investigation

Trump has attacked House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, who is leading the Democrats' impeachment inquiry

The Ukraine is not in the EU yet Sondland took part in text messages among a group of diplomats trying to set up a meeting between Trump and Zelensky - an endeavor that led to allegations that Trump leveraged nearly $400 million in aid in order to secure a promise from Zelensky to investigate Joe Biden and his son Hunter, who sat on the board of a Ukrainian gas company.

Trump has argued there was no 'quid pro quo' talk in American dealings with Kiev.
description: Donald Trump is bringing in Trey Gowdy, a staunch Republican ally and former member of Congress, to lead the fight against the impeachment inquiry into his presidency.
